column14: Notes
The three birds were in a plastic container in the luggage of a US passenger, who was fined. One bird was dead.

column13: in vitamin bottles and in tights under his pants
column14: The eggs were contained in a vitamin container and the pigeons were stuffed in envelopes and stuffed in tights under the passengers pants. One arrest
2 Slow Lorises (CITES I), 8 parrots: Moustached Parakeet, Moluccan Lory, Eclectus Parrot, and Green-naped Lorikeet

column2: red-whiskered bulbuls; magpie robins; shama thrushes
column14: Birds were contained in custom leggings worn under the passenger's pants. One arrest. The suspect had previously attempted to smuggle birds into the USA.
Three primates were also recovered with the birds from a familiy's luggage
Australian national found with 37 or 39 eggs in a specially made vest. Arrested, charged, and sentenced.

column13: Wrapped in toiled paper rolls and concealed in lining of the suitcase
column14: Only 6 birds were alive when discovered. One arrest(Guilty-plea). The suspect had previous criminal record of 2 attempted instances of finch smuggling from Guyana. Flight BW424
CITES II species concealed in wooden boxes in luggage. One Chinese man arrested.
No arrests. Birds discovered when customs officer heard bird sounds. Also 2 marmosets
8 Radiated Tortoises, 22 Leopard Tortoises, and 116 birds of 13 species. One suspect arrested.
The birds were sedated. Some were dead.
smugglers declared that it was food; suspects got away
Gyrfalcons frequently smuggled to Arab countries from Russia. One Russian man charged. Wrapped in dense cloth and hidden in bags with a cooling agent to prevent overheating.
No CITES documentation; Packed into multiple crates, 77 parrots died
Grey Parrots (CITES II) Eventually the surviving 32 parrots were returned to Africa. One arrest of a Bulgarian national. The parrots were held in four plastic containers en route from Beirut.
CITES I. One suspect (repeat offender) arrested with eggs strapped to him under his socks

The birds were wrapped in cloth and placed in pouches in the front of the Dutch passenger's pants. He had been previously arresed for wildlife smuggling attempt. This story surfaced on news outlets more than a year later in the Daily Mail and others here: http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2042474/Traveller-arrested-trying-smuggle-live-HUMMINGBIRDS-special-pouches-sewn-pants.html
Eggs were wrapped in cotton with source and parentage written on top. Likely intended for sale at a pet shop. Two suspects pled guilty.
Birds included Hill Mynahs (CITES II), Tricolored Munias, Chestnut Munias, and 35 Green Avadavats (CITES II) (20 had died). Flight PK-267
Birds had been ordered by a poultry keeper in Adelaide

Investigation began with this seizure; the Swiss Federal Customs Administration conducted an investigation which revealead that the man had already illegally introduced more than 150 eggs of parrots and pheasants in Indonesia, Thailand and Meixco; origin of eggs not established; man was a bird dealer who had "a very good network internationally"; he had 100s of birds, including the extremely rare and endangered
8 Black-necked Aracari, 8 Channel-billed Toucans, and six Red-billed Toucans (all CITES II). Didn't have CITES permits
Grey Parrots (CITES II) 29 Parrots died.

17 flamingos, 2 cranes, 120 rose-ringed parrots found in three cages bound for Muscat, Oman. The passenger accompanying the birds is allegedly assisted frequently in smuggling birds by the Sindh Wildlife Department.
Gyrfalcons (CITES I) were packed in two sports bags, surrounded by bottles of honey. The birds were bound and hooded. One Russian woman was arrested

The passenger refused to open his bags when the check in attendant requested, so the Federal Police were summonded who discovered the consignment. The passenger had two previous wildlife offenses. One bird was dead, and the rest were in poor condition as the bags were unventilated and had no food or water.

The gyrfalcons were embedded in luggage in the hold of the plane; wrapped in cloth, hooded and stored by four in the pipeline. The passenger who recorded the boxes as his luggage was unloaded and detaiend before being released pending court appearance
Gyrfalcons (CITES I) were packed in two bags. Two arrests.
The pakistani passenger smuggling the falcons was arrested.
One individual fined.
Hidden in 12 boxes in the luggage of a passenger
orangutan skull also found

Two Hill Mynas (CITES II) and other birds were found concealed on the passenger. Birds were stuffed into 10 by 20 cm cylinders which were hidden beneath grapes, pears and apples in a carry on paper bag

Red Siskin (CITES I). One arrest of Israeli national returing from Brussels. Birds were hidden in 4 boxes hidden on the body of the passenger. The birds were detected by a full-body scanner(not elaborated).
Bali Mynas (CITES I) are Critically Endangered. Discovered with four slow lorises and eight pig-nosed turtles

Suspect aged 34 was about to bard the plane; also found 88 Indian star turtles, 33 yellow-headed turtle and ploughshare tortoise (very rare protected species), 2 boa constrictors, 34 pythons, 18 tarantulas, squirrels, several species of lizards and a Gray Gabon parrot; majority of the reptiles were neclosed in plastic boxes and others were founded in different compartments in suitcases; value estimated at 18,000 euros

column2: Black Billed Amazon eggs; Yellow Billed Amazon Eggs
column14: Little known about the seizure; the article states that they were the green amazon and amazon of Jamaica, both endangered and extremely rare in captivity; of the 74 eggs, 45 birds were raised
The birds were transported in small cages and in bad shape but survived.

column2: Saffron Finches; Great-billed Seed Finches; Hooded Siskins; Nightengales;
column6: Boa Vista, Brazil; Sao Paulo, Brazil
column14: The birds were transported in cages. Two Suspects.One arrest.The luggage was exchanged Sao Paulo from the first suspect to the second.
10 birds were dead upon discovery. Some of the birds may have originated in Colombia. Suspect was fined.
One arrest. Birds were wrapped in socks and taped to the passenger's arm and leg.
The finches were discovered after an anonymous tip. Three arrests
One arrest.The birds were wrapped in cloth and then placed in pouches around the man's groin. The passenger was dutch and previously had been convicted for attempted hummingbird smuggling.
Saker Falcons (CITES II). One arrest of an Iraqi citizen.
The three birds were in individual boxes and survived the trip. One arrest
The birds were euthanized by the customs officials at the Roissy airport; "frozen alive"

The were brought into Tijuana on a private plane allegedly carried by 4 body guards of former mayor Jorge Hank Rhon, and destined for his private zoo at the Caliente Race Track. 4 arrests. Hank Rhon had previously been linked to wildlife trafficking on a pair of occasions.
The birds were euthanized
Birds were inside a pouch in the passenger's carry on, wrapped in clothes. Birds had been captured in Canary Islands municipality of Arafo. The brids were intennded for sale.
Noise was heard coming from the baggage so it was x-rayed. The birds were smuggled by a Libyan residing in Malta

column2: King parrots; Green winged macaws; Birds
column14: 67 birds born in captivity; mostly king parrots (royal parakeet?); the birds traveled with documents that had previously been used for birds
The birds were bound for a pet store in São Brás. The senders were fined and were going to court. The airline reported the shipment, and the airline may face a fine for not reporting fast enough.
The Taiwanese passenger was wearing specially made trousers. One arrest for violating Transmissible Animal Disease Prevention and Control Act.
One arrest. Finches were intended for singing competition. Finches were in cardboard toilet paper rolls, covered with netting and packaging tape. Suspect had history of trafficking.

column12: Bird got loose in passenger cabin
column14: The songbird got loose on the plane; no suspect apprehended; flight CI6
Dozens of the birds tested positive at the time for H5N1 bird flu virus.
Yellow-Collared Lovebird (CITES II)
Java Sparrow (CITES II)

Air Intelligence Unit of Mumbai Customs officials frisked three men in Mumbai and found that one was wearing two pairs of underwear. He had stashed 10 turtles in between the layers of underwear. Some of the turtles were star turtles. Officials also found that all three were also carrying two Persian cats (six total), "three Tarantula spiders (known to be extremely poisonous), 11 eggs of unknown birds, and pigeon and fish foods from the trio's bags". They were fined Rs. 1.85 lakh and "sent back". Faizan Khan, who was caught with the turtles, allegedly told police he paid between Rs5,000 and Rs10,000 per pair for the turtles. Khan has a shop in Musafir Khana, Mumbai where he sells rare wildlife. Sheikh Naushad Musa planned to sell the Persian cats for Rs50,000. Musa allegedly purchased them in Bangkok for Rs20,000 each. Musa has a farm in Pune where he trades rare species. Khan, Musa, and Sheikh Nadir Ahmed are all Indian nationals. Customs officials reported that Ahmed was paid Rs10,000 and was given free tickets by Musa for his help. Musa and Khan apparently traveled to Bankok three times in 2012.
The falcons were endangered. (Arabic could be helpful)
Yellow-Collared Lovebird (CITES II)
Java Sparrow (CITES II)
One arrest and conviction.
Gyrfalcons (CITES I), Northern Goshawk (CITES II) were hooded and one arrest of a Russian citizen was made.

column2: Hummingbirds; Jays; Hooded red siskins; Cardinals; Saffron Finches; Parakeets
column14: The birds were contained in specially constructed individual cells in a backpack with airholes and food. Only 45 survived the trip, of which 22 survived repatriation to Venezuela. A spanish national transported the birds but evaded capture.  UX071 flight Air Europa
Birds were found in pockets sewn into the pants the suspect was wearing and in a plastic cylinder in a pants pocket. One arrest
119 Falcons. The birds were sold to a UAE-royal prince and then discovered after a tip to local authorities. 11 Arrests.
The birds were bound for a Bahraini dignitary. The Bahraini smuggler attempted to smuggle the birds out using re-export permits.

column13: in small boxes hidden in his suitcase
column14: Belgian, aged 49, was arrested at the airport; birds estimated to be worth 500 euros each (as of 2012). 24 west bluebirds and 18 bullfinches
Gyrfalcons (CITES I), one arrest of a Russian national
Four chinese suspects arrested. Also carrying 189 pangolin scales

column2: Birds; African grey parrots; budgerigaries; rainbow lorikeets; golden mantled rosellas; green parakeets
column14: 30 African Grey Parrots, 100 Budgerigar, 10 rainbow Lorikeets, 10 golden mantled rosella, 10 green parakeets. 10 marmoset monkeys were also recovered. The animals were transported in 9 cages, two for monkeys, 7 for the birds. One Bangladeshi customs officer arrested, one suspect escaped when the pair were confronted as they attempted to leave the airport in a van.
Birds mistreated by veterinarians on the ground. Came from Mexico City
4 Parrots, 2 other, 6 rodents, 3 kangaroos
13 birds were dead on discovery, and the remaining 4 were put down. The birds were placed in small wooden crates and placed in three suitcases.
The birds were held in individual wooden cages in suitcases. These birds are often bred for fighting.
The birds were held in individual wooden cages in suitcases. These birds are often bred for fighting.
Birds-of-paradise (CITES II). One bird was infected with H5N1 virus. 39 birds were dead on arrival, remaining 21 were put down. 2 Czech smugglers were detained but released.

column2: Wattled Jacanas; Silver Teals; Nacunda Nighthawks; Whistling Herons
column14: Three Maltese nationals were detained after the dead birds were discovered.
The birds were held in the susect's backpack. One arrest.
5 Galahs (CITES II) and 2 parrots. The birds were found on board an indonesian army aircraft in a bag as the plane refueled. No charges against the perpetrators.

column2: Thick-billed seed finches; Chestnut-bellied seed finches; Picolets
column14: The birds were wrapped up as christmas presents.

The birds were believed to belong to Egyptian peacekeepers in Bukavu; Congolese authorities suspect peacekeepers have resorted to fraudulet means to acquire and transport these animals; authorities believe the attempt to use UN flags was a means to mark the packages as diplomatic or official order to escape certain controls. Allegations that each solider (27 rotating one) in Bukavu on the MONUSCO mission in Kindu each individually purchased a parrot; CAA officials allegedly complicit and the peacekeepers also received the necessary approvals from the Congolese Control Office (OCC) to acquire the parrots
Birds were stuffed in hair curlers. The smuggler was discovered when two of the wrapped birds fell on the tarmac as he assisted another passenger to board the plane.
Eggs were seized and destroyed under domestic regulations that prevent importation of poultry products.
One arrest. The birds were packed into three suitcases in cags without food, water or ventilation.
One arrest. All the birds were dead upon discovery. They were being smuggled for birdfighting
Two arrests. Parrots returned to Belgium.

column12: Attracted attention of customs with "the very wide trouser legs"
column14: Attempt to export to USA; USA resident; the little singer sporophile is a species of sparrow with a yellow throat, native to Cuba, protected but not endangered
German citizen arrested in connection with the seizure.

column2: Melodious Laughing Thrushes; White rumped shamas
column14: Melodious laughing Thrushes(CITES II), 3 white rumped shamas were wrapped in aluminum foil and put in black trash bags. All the birds died en route or within a few days of interception. One arrest. The birds were purchased in HCMC.
Two arrests. parrots were Grey parrots and Eclectus parrots.
A customs officer noticed a strange bulge in the smuggler's pants and a strange gait. 2 of the 66 birds were dead and several had their beaks sealed shut.
One Czech national arrested.
Birds-of-paradies (CITES II) were being transported by a German smuggler.
Customs officials noticed a bulge in a Russian passenger's pants and discovered the two birds sewn into the lining of his pants. One arrest.
This was a pet parrot that had traveled with a family from the UK to Turkey, then back after a number of years, with potentially bad CITES documentation accidentally
White Cockatoo (CITES II). One arrest. Brought from Lisbon. The birds were packed in a small plastic container, in the luggage of a Brazilian national.
470 Parrots (CITES II), 400 spotted doves. Suspects escaped
Saker Falcons (CITES II). One arrest. Birds were bound and blindfolded in a carry-on sports bag.
Birds were stuffed into hair curling tubes which were stiched into hidden pockets inside the jacket. One arrest and conviction of a Canadian national.
Keel-billed toucans(CITES II) were sent by a pet shop with out of date CITES paperwork. Both birds died in custody.

column2: White-rumped shamas; Red-whiskered Bulbus; Magpie Robins
column14: Arrived on flight from HCMC. Individually contained in pvc tubes without food and waater. Eight of the birds died. One arrest. 9 White-rumped shama, 2 red whiskered bublbul, 1 magpie robin
3 Saker falcons (CITES II), 2 peregrine falcons (CITES I) were found in 2 wooden boxes. Birds were in poor condition.
16 males and 17 females were found in the sports bag of a male Turkish traveler in a cage.
The toucans were bound for another continent.
11 Chinese Hwamei (CITES II). Birds were found under tinfoil and clothing in the American passenger's luggage. One arrest and conviction.
Disguised in a box labeled as "handicraft gifts"
The three birds were wrapped in tape and stuffed in a plastic bottle. The birds were seized in violation of teh Lacey act and Migratory Bird treaty
Flight IB 6674
Saker Falcons (CITES II) were found in two suitcases.

column2: Golden blue macaws; Yellow Crested cockatoos; White-crested cockatoos
column14: Suspicious airline staff tipped off the Profepa to discover the shipment. Birds were contained in small boxes of wood and wire.

Peregrine Falcon (CITES I)-These are especially rare as the eggs were albino, only found in Chile due to a genetic mutation. Discovered in an incubator with the suspect. One of the four eggs eventually hatched and the chick was reintegrated into a nest in Chile. One arrest--Jeffrey Lendrum, previously arrested and sentenced in UK for bird trafficking.
One arrest of an american national, fined $75,000. The birds were hidden in hair curlers in the passenger's handbag. The flight was bound for JFK airport. Flight BW526
One arrest of an Argentine national.
Several of the birds were injured.
Florida man arrested. 6 Birds in a fanny pack, three in his groin area.
One man fined 50,000 Rs
Also in the consignment were 11 tarsiers, 11 snakes, and 11 monitor lizards. The shipment was found via a tip earlier in the month that a shipment was incoming.

50 New Zealand Kakariki, 20 rosella parrots, 60 red-rumped Australian parakeets, 12 red goldfinches (speciment of Venezuela and Colombia); each bird estiamted to be worth about 4200 euros; Belgian national had already tried to pass the birds earlier in the week
The eggs were prohibited from entry by regulations to protect against HPAI and END.

column2: White-rumped shamas; Oriental Shamas; Melodious Laughing thrushes
column14: Melodious laughingthrush(CITES II). The birds were found taped to the passengers legs and in special pouches in his checked bag.
Green-Cheeked Parakeets (CITES II). One arrest of a Maldvivan citizen.
Birds were stuffed into plastic tubes. One arrest and fined. The birds were being taken to New York. Allegedly the birds were given to the passenger for transport to someone else.
Birds were stuffed into plastic tubes. One arrest and fined. The birds were being taken to Toronto for personal use
